Trump directs agency heads to review funding for NGOs President Donald Trump sent a memorandum Friday directing agency and department heads across the federal government to review all funding that agencies provide to nongovernmental organizations, or NGOs. The memorandum claims that many NGOs “are engaged in actions that actively undermine the security, prosperity, and safety of the American people” and that it’s the policy of the Trump administration “to stop funding NGOs that undermine the national interest.” The memo directs agency heads to “align future funding decisions with the interests of the United States and with the goals and priorities of my Administration.” The memorandum is the latest in a series of efforts by Trump to scrutinize federal spending on humanitarian efforts and other forms of international aid. In some countries, especially less developed ones, NGOs are sometimes the only providers of reproductive health care. Last month, Trump reinstated a policy that restricts access to safe abortions in counties that rely on U.S.-funded programs. Last week, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem said she would cut off agency funding for NGOs that she said were using federal funds to assist in illegal migration into the United States. The administration has also moved to shrink the U.S. Agency for International Development, which administers humanitarian aid programs. The administration has put a vast swath of employees on leave and notified all overseas staff that they will be recalled within a month. Trump had also issued a sweeping freeze on new funding for almost all U.S. foreign assistance, but Secretary of State Marco Rubio last week approved a waiver for lifesaving humanitarian assistance.
